english: pair; couple; yoked; to plow in pairs

etymology.description: semantic: 耒 (“tilling tool”) + phonetic: 禺 (OC *ŋo, *ŋos), paired working in the fields.
etymology.interpretation: 耒 signals an agricultural context, while 禺 supplies the sound that later developed to ǒu. Together they convey the idea of yoked or paired work in the fields, extending to senses like coupling in general.

examples.chinese: 科学家研究粒子之间的耦合(科學家研究粒子之間的耦合)。
examples.pinyin: Kēxuéjiā yánjiū lìzǐ zhījiān de ǒuhé.
examples.english: Scientists study the coupling between particles.

examples.chinese: 春耕时，农夫用两头牛耦耕田地(春耕時，農夫用兩頭牛耦耕田地)。
examples.pinyin: Chūngēng shí, nóngfū yòng liǎng tóu niú ǒugēng tiándì.
examples.english: During spring plowing, the farmer uses two oxen yoked together to plow the fields.

examples.chinese: 这些元件耦合得很紧密(這些元件耦合得很緊密)。
examples.pinyin: Zhèxiē yuánjiàn ǒuhé de hěn jǐnmì.
